semantic_title: Coding Symptoms and Signs When Diagnosis Not Established
section_path: Section IV > D. Codes that describe symptoms and signs

content.full_text: Codes that describe symptoms and signs, as opposed to diagnoses, are acceptable for reporting purposes when a diagnosis has not been established (confirmed) by the provider. Chapter 18 of ICD-10-CM, Symptoms, Signs, and Abnormal Clinical and Laboratory Findings Not Elsewhere Classified (codes R00-R99) contain many, but not all codes for symptoms. (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L47)
content.summary: Authorizes use of symptom and sign codes when definitive diagnoses are not established, with specific reference to Chapter 18 codes (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L47)
key_concepts: Symptom and sign codes acceptable when diagnosis not established (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L46)
Provider must not have confirmed a diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 113, L46)
Chapter 18 (R00-R99) contains many symptom codes (Evidence: pg no: 113, L46-L47)
Not all symptom codes are in Chapter 18 (Evidence: pg no: 113, L47)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use symptom and sign codes when diagnosis not established by provider (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L46)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a provider has not confirmed a definitive diagnosis, symptom codes are appropriate for reporting (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L46)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Chapter 18 (R00-R99) contains many but not all symptom codes (Evidence: pg no: 113, L46-L47)
detailed_rules.explanation: While Chapter 18 is the primary location for symptom codes, symptom codes may exist in other chapters (Evidence: pg no: 113, L46-L47)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Determine if provider has established a definitive diagnosis
Step 2: If no diagnosis established, identify documented symptoms and signs
Step 3: Search Chapter 18 (R00-R99) for appropriate symptom codes
Step 4: Check other chapters if symptom not found in Chapter 18
Step 5: Code all documented symptoms and signs

code_ranges.description: Symptoms, Signs, and Abnormal Clinical and Laboratory Findings Not Elsewhere Classified (Evidence: pg no: 113, L46-L47)
usage_rules: Contains many but not all symptom codes (Evidence: pg no: 113, L47)
Use when diagnosis not established (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L46)

code_categories_mentioned: Chapter 18 - Symptoms, Signs, and Abnormal Clinical and Laboratory Findings

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient presents with chest pain, no definitive diagnosis established
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Chief complaint: Chest pain for 2 hours. Physical exam: Normal heart sounds, no murmurs. Assessment: Chest pain, etiology unclear. Plan: EKG, chest x-ray, follow up.
step_by_step: Step 1: Confirm no definitive diagnosis established
Step 3: Search Chapter 18 for chest pain code

correct_coding.rationale: Symptom codes acceptable when diagnosis not established by provider (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L46)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should not assign definitive diagnosis code when provider has not established diagnosis
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Assigning diagnosis codes when only symptoms documented

warnings: Do not assign diagnosis codes when provider has not established diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L46)
best_practices: Use symptom codes when diagnosis not confirmed (Evidence: pg no: 113, L45-L46)
Check Chapter 18 first for symptom codes (Evidence: pg no: 113, L46-L47)
Remember symptom codes may exist outside Chapter 18
common_mistakes: Assigning definitive diagnosis when only symptoms documented
Only looking in Chapter 18 for all symptom codes
Not coding symptoms when diagnosis unclear
tips: Chapter 18 contains many but not all symptom codes (Evidence: pg no: 113, L47)
implementation_notes: Requires clear documentation of diagnostic uncertainty
May require provider clarification on diagnostic status
clinical_context: Outpatient encounters often involve diagnostic workup
Symptoms may be the only documented findings initially
